DataElement.preferredName: Bladder Carcinoma Other Metastatic Involvement Anatomic Site Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text description of anatomic sites of metastatic bladder carcinoma that are different from the ones previously identified.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the bladder epithelium.  Approximately 90% of the bladder carcinomas are transitional cell carcinomas.  The remainder are squamous cell carcinomas, adenocarcinomas and small cell neuroendocrine carcinomas._information related to evidence of the spread of cancer from a tumor located in the distensible musculomembranous organ that stores urine to another part of the body._Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned._A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the bladder epithelium.  Approximately 90% of the bladder carcinomas are transitional cell carcinomas.  The remainder are squamous cell carcinomas, adenocarcinomas and small cell neuroendocrine carcinomas.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the bladder epithelium.  Approximately 90% of the bladder carcinomas are transitional cell carcinomas.  The remainder are squamous cell carcinomas, adenocarcinomas and small cell neuroendocrine carcinomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.:(MET-uh-STAT-ik) Having to do with metastasis, which is the spread of cancer from one part of the body to another.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
A term referring to the clinical or pathologic observation of a tumor extension from its original site of growth to another anatomic site.
To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.
